quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6, Quiz 6: Capacitive Reactance - Advanced Concepts
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: If the frequency of an AC circuit is tripled while the capacitance remains constant, what happens to the capacitive reactance ($X_C$)?
options: It is reduced to one-third of its original value.
It increases by a factor of nine.
questions.explanation: $X_C = 1/(2\pi fC) \propto 1/f$. Tripling $f$ reduces $X_C$ to 1/3: $X_C' = 1/(2\pi × 3f × C) = (1/3)X_C$. This shows capacitors are more conductive at higher frequencies.

questions.question: In a phasor diagram, what is the angle between the voltage across a capacitor and the current through it?
questions.explanation: Current leads voltage by 90° in ideal capacitor. Phasor representation: if voltage phasor at 0°, current phasor at +90°. Phase difference $\phi = -90°$ (voltage lags current).

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct unit for the product $2\pi f C$?
questions.explanation: $2\pi f C$ has units: $(\text{s}^{-1}) × (\text{C/V}) = \text{C/(V·s)} = \text{A/V} = \text{S}$ (siemens). Since $X_C = 1/(2\pi f C)$, the product is the reciprocal of ohms.

questions.question: A capacitor is said to be a "frequency-dependent resistor." For which type of signal does it offer the least opposition?
options: It offers the same opposition to all.
questions.explanation: $X_C = 1/(2\pi f C) → 0$ as $f → \infty$. High frequencies pass easily through capacitors (low reactance). DC ($f = 0$) encounters infinite reactance (blocks DC).

questions.question: What is the power factor of a circuit containing only an ideal capacitor?
questions.explanation: Power factor = $\cos\phi$, where $\phi = -90°$ (voltage lags current by 90°). $\cos(-90°) = 0$. Zero power factor means no average power dissipation—all energy is stored and returned.

questions.question: If you connect two identical capacitors in parallel in an AC circuit, the total capacitive reactance will:
questions.explanation: Parallel capacitors: $C_{total} = C_1 + C_2 = 2C$ (if identical). $X_C \propto 1/C$, so $X_C' = 1/(2C) = (1/2)X_C$. Halving reactance doubles current for same voltage.

questions.question: Which equation represents the instantaneous current ($i$) in a capacitive circuit if $v = V_{peak} \sin(\omega t)$?
questions.explanation:
$i = C(dv/dt) = C × d/dt(V_{peak}\sin\omega t) = \omega C V_{peak} \cos\omega t = I_{peak}\cos\omega t = I_{peak}\sin(\omega t + 90^\circ)$.
Current leads voltage by 90°.

questions.question: What happens to the energy stored in a capacitor during the quarter-cycle when the AC voltage is dropping from its peak to zero?
options: It is dissipated as heat in the dielectric.
It is returned to the AC source.
It remains stored in the electric field.
It is converted into a magnetic field.
questions.explanation: Energy $U = \frac{1}{2}CV^2$. As $V$ decreases from peak to zero, stored energy decreases. This energy flows back to source (current flows opposite to voltage). Capacitors exchange energy with source, not dissipate it.

questions.question: In an AC circuit, the "opposition" provided by a capacitor is called reactance rather than resistance because:
options: It does not obey Ohm's Law.
It does not convert electrical energy into thermal energy.
It depends on the material of the wires.
questions.explanation: Reactance ($X$) stores and returns energy; resistance ($R$) dissipates energy as heat. Both obey AC Ohm's Law ($V = IZ$ where $Z$ is impedance), but differ in energy handling.

questions.question: If an AC source has an angular frequency ($\omega$) of $100\ \text{rad/s}$ and is connected to a $50\mu\text{F}$ capacitor, what is the reactance?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered advanced capacitive reactance concepts including angular frequency relationships, energy exchange, phasor analysis, and parallel combinations.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Deep understanding of capacitor behavior in AC circuits. Review the energy exchange process and the mathematical representation of phase relationships.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Relationship between $X_C$, $\omega$, and $C$, 2) Energy storage and return in capacitors, 3) Phase relationships in mathematical form, 4) Parallel/series capacitor effects on reactance.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review capacitive reactance formula, how phase relationships arise from $i = C(dv/dt)$, and the concept of reactance vs. resistance.
